natural problem:
Let $f(x) = |g(x^3)|$. If $g$ is an odd function, is $f$ odd, even, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither".

a_0.formal problem:
definition 
  odd_function :: "('a::group_add \<Rightarrow> 'a) \<Rightarrow> bool"
where 
  "odd_function f \<equiv> \<forall>x. f (-x) = - f x"

definition 
  even_function :: "('a::group_add \<Rightarrow> 'a) \<Rightarrow> bool"
where 
  "even_function f \<equiv> \<forall>x. f (-x) = f x"

theorem
fixes g f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "odd_function g"
and h1 : "f x \<equiv> abs (g (x powr 3))"
shows  "even_function f"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x) = |g(x^3)|$. If $g$ is an odd function, is $f$ odd, even, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither". The final Answer is \text{even}
 ### Proof
 $$f(-x) = |g((-x)^3)| = |g(-x^3)|$$Since $g$ is odd, $g(-x) = -g(x)$. Then, $$f(-x) = |-g(x^3)| = |g(x^3)| = f(x).$$Hence, $f$ is $\boxed{\text{even}}$.
 *)

definition 
  odd_function :: "('a::group_add \<Rightarrow> 'a) \<Rightarrow> bool"
where 
  "odd_function f \<equiv> \<forall>x. f (-x) = - f x"

definition 
  even_function :: "('a::group_add \<Rightarrow> 'a) \<Rightarrow> bool"
where 
  "even_function f \<equiv> \<forall>x. f (-x) = f x"

theorem
fixes g f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "odd_function g"
and h1 : "f x \<equiv> abs (g (x powr 3))"
shows  "even_function f"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that $g$ is an odd function (meaning that $g(-x) = -g(x)$ for all $x$), and $f(x)$ is defined as the absolute value of $g(x^3)$, prove that $f$ is an even function (meaning that $f(-x) = f(x)$ for all $x$).

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x = - g (-x)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = abs (g (x powr 3))"
shows  "\<forall> x. f x = f (-x)"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x) = |g(x^3)|$. If $g$ is an odd function, is $f$ odd, even, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither". The final Answer is \text{even}
 ### Proof
 $$f(-x) = |g((-x)^3)| = |g(-x^3)|$$Since $g$ is odd, $g(-x) = -g(x)$. Then, $$f(-x) = |-g(x^3)| = |g(x^3)| = f(x).$$Hence, $f$ is $\boxed{\text{even}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x = - g (-x)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = abs (g (x powr 3))"
shows  "\<forall> x. f x = f (-x)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given two functions $f$ and $g$ defined by $g(x) = -g(-x)$ and $f(x) = |g(x^3)|$, for every real number $x$, prove that $f(x) = f(-x)$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g (-x) = - g x"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = abs (g (x powr 3))"
shows  "\<forall> x. f (-x) = f x"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither". The final Answer is \text{even}
 ### Proof
 $$f(-x) = |g((-x)^3)| = |g(-x^3)|$$Since $g$ is odd, $g(-x) = -g(x)$. Then, $$f(-x) = |-g(x^3)| = |g(x^3)| = f(x).$$Hence, $f$ is $\boxed{\text{even}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g (-x) = - g x"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = abs (g (x powr 3))"
shows  "\<forall> x. f (-x) = f x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: For all real numbers $x$, if $g$ is an odd function (i.e., $g(-x) = -g(x)$ for all $x$), and $f(x) = |g(x^3)|$, then $f$ is an even function (i.e., $f(-x) = f(x)$ for all $x$).

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g(-x) = -g(x)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f(x) = abs(g(x powr 3))"
shows  "\<forall> x. f(-x) = f(x)" (*f is an even function*)
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x) = |g(x^3)|$. If $g$ is an odd function, is $f$ odd, even, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither". The final Answer is \text{even}
 ### Proof
 $$f(-x) = |g((-x)^3)| = |g(-x^3)|$$Since $g$ is odd, $g(-x) = -g(x)$. Then, $$f(-x) = |-g(x^3)| = |g(x^3)| = f(x).$$Hence, $f$ is $\boxed{\text{even}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g(-x) = -g(x)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f(x) = abs(g(x powr 3))"
shows  "\<forall> x. f(-x) = f(x)" (*f is an even function*)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If $g$ is an odd function, such that $g(-x) = -g(x)$ for all $x$, and a function $f$ is defined as $f(x) = |g(x^3)|$, then $f$ is an even function, meaning that $f(-x) = f(x)$ for all $x$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g (-x) = - g x"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = abs (g (x powr 3))"
shows  "\<forall> x. f (-x) = f x"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f(x) = |g(x^3)|$. If $g$ is an odd function, is $f$ odd, even, or neither?

Enter "odd", "even", or "neither". The final Answer is \text{even}
 ### Proof
 $$f(-x) = |g((-x)^3)| = |g(-x^3)|$$Since $g$ is odd, $g(-x) = -g(x)$. Then, $$f(-x) = |-g(x^3)| = |g(x^3)| = f(x).$$Hence, $f$ is $\boxed{\text{even}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g (-x) = - g x"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = abs (g (x powr 3))"
shows  "\<forall> x. f (-x) = f x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
